Here's an open-minded thought experiment for you:
Suppose Gravity is not a field or a force, but only curved space-time caused by the mere presence of matter.

Would that mean that:
Gravity has no energy, but only is a reflection of kinetic energy that is already contained in the particles moving through Gravitational curvature?
Gravity is not quantizable?
No singularity at the "geometric center" of a black hole, because there is no "geometric center"; the event horizon surface IS the "real center" of the black hole?
The mass of a black hole is entirely contained at the event horizon surface, and thus when time stops at the surface, the movement of matter towards the "geometric center" also stops?
There is no existence or "reality" deeper/below the event horizon surface, and thus the event horizon surface of a black hole is essentially an "edge" of the universe?
What if General Relativity (GR) slightly differs from Quantum Physics (QP), not because GR is "not quite right", but rather because QP is not quite right?

Think outside of the box. That's where the great discoveries are waiting to be found.
"It ain't what you don't know that gets you into trouble. It's what you know for sure that just ain't so." -- Mark Twain

I am SSSSSO sick tired of the same premise black holes keep getting in this bad PR hammering as the boogeyman of the universe. Try to see it this less dirty cheap dramatic way:
Black holes are crystallization points in the universe which allow mass to cluster and form galaxies. Without those black holes mass would be much more evenly distributed throughout dark space and BECAUSE of the lack of them the whole universe would be probably a MUCH darker space. Black holes are like a dirt particle in the air which allows a snow crystal to form a condensation point which attracts mass and stir it up well in those large structures known as galaxy, kneading, compressing and churning the mass of stars and many ex-stars which produced all the heavier elements into what we know as planets in solar system, making life even just possible BECAUSE of their presence.
But our stupid and short-sighted attitude as human beings, not to mention the sensationalist nature of our media we just focus on their negative destructive side of them were I focus more on their, in IMHO, essential existence for us and other most likely life existing throughout the universe. As essential as most likely every higher life (beyond microbes, not to mention possible intelligent life) needs as requirement on a planet a stabilizing force to keep the rotation axis of a planet stable to allow long enough stable conditions to evolve beyond primitive forms of life like our moon. Most exo-planets we will find in the goldilock zones of other stars might have the chance to develop simple life, maybe even up to some alge or even plant life. But a moon as stabilizer for higher forms is as important as a black hole to compressing and mixing the original hydrogen and helium from the first stars from the origin of the universe to make any heavier element even possible.
I just say black holes deserve a better PR then this cheap freak circus PR the media and even their scientists which explore them give them. Maybe, the universe allows it, we live long enough to grow up, we can see them in that more appreciative light they deserve in my opinion.
With those jets they produce you might even able to call them to some degree a recycling stations as they not consume everything but after ripping matter apart throwing some back into the surrounding space.

They don’t exist. The theory is based on two false assumptions: one, that our models of gravitation are correct. We know they are not, they break down at very small and very large scales. Two, that electromagnetic forces don’t play a significant role in the regions where these black holes are theorized to exist, i.e. the center of galaxies.
Just like dark matter. “We know it’s there, we just can’t... quite... detect them with anything...”
For kicks, yet another thing modern cosmology gets wrong is red shift. Look up Halton Arp, he catalogued thousands of examples of stellar objects exhibiting vastly different red shift values depending on which region was observed.
